column4: it is also used for when you want to do fresh installs of the new release and don't want to have to do backups
how does ubuntu handle between versions with a separate home? i've been thinking about doing that but i'm really not sure how the legacy config files would work out
I have never had any issues, your milleage may vary. I don't see why the configs would change so much from one version to next that it would break things
do you only use it for upgrades or for btween distros?
I bleed ubuntu brown :)
do you ever get prompted with anything that there's a config mismatch or that older configs have to be replaced? or is it usually all automated?
nope never. I have done upgrades and fresh installs and use the same /home. no issues
huh.. what versions have you gone between?
I have been upgrading since 5.10 and also doing fresh installs. last 4 versions with same /home
how do you usually handle reinstalling stuff you had installed before?
i've seen stuff like that, including stuff with dpkg -l, but it just seems like that could lead to a world of hurt with packages having different names
the package names very rarely if ever change names
is that clone method how you reinstall stuff?
from one distro to the next the names change but within the same distro not normally
yes I have used it before.
no issues? at all?
the seperate home, for me at least, is more about not having to backup my media files when doing a fresh install. I don't really mind having to re-install apps and such if I have to
ah, yeah that could work for me. i've held back upgrading ubuntu for a while just because things seem to be working and i don't want to go through some headache of stuff not working.
if you don't need to upgrade then don't :)

welll a lot of things i've looked over wanting to do require newer stuff. i tried to install some haskell stuff recently and wound up upgrading libc and had to spend a day uninstalling and reinstalling packages until things were right again. upgrading would probably be good for me.
